title: HBr and HF IMFs and Bonds

content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="H B r, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

(a) In the following table, list all of the types of intermolecular forces present in pure samples of <math alttext="H B r, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> and <math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.
Liquid<math alttext="H B r, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>Intermolecularforces present

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="H B r, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> and <math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="italic">l</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

(a) In the following table, list all of the types of intermolecular forces present in pure samples of <math alttext="H B r, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> and <math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.
Liquid<math alttext="H B r, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math><math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>Intermolecularforces present

(b) The enthalpy of vaporization, <math alttext="delta H naught sub vaporization" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup></math>, for each liquid is provided in the following table.

Liquid
 <math alttext="H B r, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>
 <math alttext="H F, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>

<math alttext="delta H naught sub vaporization" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup></math>
 <math alttext="17.3 kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mn>17.3</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>kJ</mi> <mo>/</mo> <mi>mol</mi> </math>
 <math alttext="25.2 kilojoules per mole" overflow="scroll"> <mn>25.2</mn> <mspace width="0.25em"> </mspace> <mi>kJ</mi> <mo>/</mo> <mi>mol</mi> </math>

(i) Based on the types and relative strengths of intermolecular forces, explain why <math alttext="delta H naught sub vaporization" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mrow><mi>v</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow><mtext>∘</mtext></msubsup></math> of <math alttext="H F, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> is greater than that of <math alttext="H B r, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

(ii) Calculate the amount of thermal energy, in <math alttext="kilojoules" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>kJ</mi></math>, required to vaporize <math alttext="6.85 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6.85</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></math> of <math alttext="H F, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

(c) Based on the arrangement of electrons in the <math alttext="B r " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Br</mi></math> and <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></math> atoms, explain why the bond length in an <math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HBr</mi></math> molecule is greater than that in an <math alttext="H F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>HF</mi></math> molecule.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
